isis.stitle: VT-365 Diesel Engine Diagnostics (2002) - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEMS DIAGNOSTICS - Circuit Diagnostics - Air Management System (AMS)

figure.caption: Function Diagram for the Air Management System (AMS)

calloutgroup.callout1: EVRT™ turbocharger assembly with mounting bracket

svcprocinfo.para: The Function Diagram for the AMS includes the following:

svcsubproc.title: AMS Operation
svcsubproc.para: The Variable Geometry Turbocharger (VGT) system controls internal actuated vanes to change the flow characteristics of the exhaust gas through the turbine, which causes a variation in the boost pressure produced by the turbocharger.

The VGT system is closed loop using the EBP sensor as the feedback. The vane position is adjusted to reach the desired exhaust back pressure. Vane position management is accomplished by changing the direction of engine oil flow in the VGT actuator. The ECM sends a pulse-width modulated signal to the VGT actuator causing the vanes to move. Varying the vane position changes the flow characteristics of the exhaust gas through the turbine housing and additionally results in a change of boost pressure.

The ECM calculates the appropriate desired exhaust back pressure in response to the changing engine speed, fuel desired, operator demand, engine operating temperatures, and altitude. The components involved with the control of the VGT include the following:
The Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) system controls the amount of exhaust gas being introduced to the engine intake manifold by modulating the EGR valve.

The EGR system is closed loop using the EGR valve Position (EGRP) sensor as the feedback. The EGRP is adjusted to reach the desired EGR valve position. The ECM sends a pulse-width modulated signal to the EGR valve actuator causing the EGR valve to move. The actual exhaust gas flow from the exhaust manifold to the intake manifold is regulated by calculating the pressure differential and the opening and closing of the EGR valve.
The EGR valve's fully closed position is calibrated each time the ECM is powered up to allow some compensation of carbon build up on the EGR valve.
When the engine operating temperatures and conditions are appropriate, the EGR valve will be exercised when the engine is shut down to reduce the chance of a stuck EGR valve.

The ECM calculates the appropriate desired EGR valve position in response to the changing engine speed, fuel desired, operator demand, engine operating temperatures, exhaust back pressure, boost pressure and altitude. Components involved with the control of the EGR include the following:
The ECM continuously monitors the Air Management System (AMS). When the ECM detects a fault in the any of the interdependent systems, the ECM will set a DTC and illuminate the amber ENGINE lamp.

The Electronic Variable Response Turbocharger (EVRT™) is continuously monitored by the ECM using the exhaust back pressure and the EVRT pulse-width modulated signal's duty cycle. A DTC is logged when the ECM determines that the duty cycle required to reach the desired boost or exhaust backpressure is greater or less than the ECM's pre-programmed expected values.
Service bay diagnostics for the EVRT are available and can be performed using the Electronic Service Tool (EST).

The Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) system is continuously monitored by the ECM using the EGR valve position signal. When the EBP, MAP, MAT, EGRP, or BAP sensor has an out of range fault (high or low), the EGR duty cycle will default to a pre-programmed value and close the valve.
Service bay diagnostics for the EGR are available and can be performed using the Electronic Service Tool (EST).
DTCs are read using the Electronic Service Tool (EST) or by counting the flashes from the amber and red ENGINE lamp.

note.para: Before proceeding make sure all sensor, injector and actuator electrical DTCs have been repaired. Follow the procedures outlined in Section 6 or Performance Diagnostics form EGED-250.

entry.para: DTC 343 is set by the ECM when the exhaust backpressure is greater than 260 kPa (37.7 psi).
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.
VGT valve or vanes stuck closed
VGT Control Circuit short to B+

para.emph: DTC 344 - Exhaust back pressure above spec with engine OFF

entry.para: DTC 344 is set by the ECM when the EBP is greater than 300 kPa (43.5 psi) when engine is off or being cranked.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.
EBP sensor or tube line plugged

para.emph: DTC 345 - Faults detected during VGT portion of AMS test

entry.para: DTC 345 is set by the ECM during the AMS test when the ECM measures the EBP and does not see the expected response in pressures.
Intake / CAC system leak (pipes, loose clamps, hoses)
Check sensor signal voltage in MAP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.
Do KOEO standard test and VGT circuit diagnostics.

para.emph: DTC 346 - Faults detected during EGR portion of AMS test

entry.para: DTC 346 is set by the ECM during AMS test when the ECM measures EBP and EGRP and does not see the expected response in pressures versus position.
Check sensor signal voltage in EGR circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.
Do KOEO standard test and EGR circuit diagnostics.

para.emph: DTC 351 - Change in exhaust back pressure did not occur when expected

entry.para: DTC 351 is set by the ECM when less than 14.5 kPa (2.1 psi) is detected between Key ON and 2500 rpm.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.

para.emph: DTC 353 - VGT control over duty cycle

entry.para: DTC 353 is set when the ECM overcompensates by increasing duty cycle to the VGT to achieve desired boost/backpressure.
Intake / CAC system leak (pipes, loose clamps, hoses)
Check sensor signal voltage in BAP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in MAP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in ICP circuit diagnostics.
Check previous repairs. Do performance diagnostics.
Do KOEO standard test and VGT circuit diagnostics.

para.emph: DTC 354 - VGT control under duty cycle

entry.para: DTC 354 is set when the ECM overcompensates by decreasing duty cycle to the VGT to achieve the desired boost/backpressure.
Check sensor signal voltage in BAP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in MAP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in ICP circuit diagnostics.
Check previous repairs. Do performance diagnostics.

DTC 355 is set when the ECM detects turbo over speed several times in a specific period of time (dependent on ECM calibration). Turbo speed is estimated by engine speed, boost pressure, and barometric pressure.
Intake / CAC system leak (pipes, loose clamps, hoses)
Check sensor signal voltage in BAP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in MAP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.

para.emph: DTC 361 - VGT control input (MAP/EBP) above/below desired level

entry.para: DTC 361 is set when the ECM detects an in range error in the MAP/EBP signal.
Intake / CAC system leak (pipes, loose clamps, hoses)
Check sensor signal voltage in BAP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in MAP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in ICP circuit diagnostics.
Check previous repairs. Do performance diagnostics.
Do KOEO standard test and VGT circuit diagnostics.
Exhaust restriction or leak (muffler or catalytic converter)

para.emph: DTC 365 - EGR valve position above / below desired level

entry.para: DTC 365 is set when the actual EGR Valve Position does not match desired.
Check sensor signal voltage in EGR circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.
Do KOEO standard test and EGR circuit diagnostics.

para.emph: DTC 366 - EGR valve duty operating out of expected range

entry.para: DTC 366 is set when the ECM has overcompensated by increasing or decreasing EGR duty to achieve the desired EGRP.
Check sensor signal voltage in EGR circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in BAP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in EBP circuit diagnostics.
Check sensor signal voltage in MAP circuit diagnostics.

para.emph: DTC 367 - Improper position signal when EGR valve is expected closed

entry.para: DTC 367 is set when the ECM detects the EGR Valve position is out of desired range during Key ON (signal voltage >2.5V).
EGR Valve position sensor bias high
Check sensor signal voltage in EGR circuit diagnostics.
